Overview: It is possible to extract OS, domain and SMB server information from the Session Setup AndX Response packet which is generated during NTLM authentication. Detected SMB workgroup: WORKGROUP Detected SMB server: Windows 7 Ultimate 6.1 Detected OS: Windows 7 Ultimate 7601 Service Pack 1

nvt.name: Using NetBIOS to retrieve information from a Windows host

result.description:
The following 3 NetBIOS names have been gathered : GUEST-PC = This is the computer name registered for workstation services by a WINS client. WORKGROUP = Workgroup / Domain name GUEST-PC = Computer name The remote host has the following MAC address on its adapter : 00:0a:11:00:af:ff
If you do not want to allow everyone to find the NetBios name of your computer, you should filter incoming traffic to this port.

Distributed Computing Environment (DCE) services running on the remote host can be enumerated by connecting on port 135 and doing the appropriate queries.
An attacker may use this fact to gain more knowledge about the remote host.
Solution : filter incoming traffic to this port.

CVE : CVE-1999-0554, CVE-1999-0548
nmap thinks unknown is running on this port

Overview: This script detects the running 'rpc.rquotad' service on the host.
Vulnerability Insight: The flaw is caused due to error in the 'rpc.rquotad' service. If this service is running then disable it as it may become a security threat.
Impact: Successful exploitation could allow attackers to execute to gain information about NFS services including user/system quotas.
Impact Level: System
Fix: No solution or patch is available as on 11th August, 2011. Information regarding this issue will be updated once the solution details are available.
Workaround: Modify /etc/inetd.conf to disable the rpc.rquotad service.
References: http://osvdb.org/show/osvdb/9726 http://xforce.iss.net/xforce/xfdb/265 http://www.exploitsearch.net/index.php?q=CVE-1999-0625 http://www.iss.net/security_center/reference/vuln/rquotad.htm CVE : CVE-1999-0625

nvt.name: Microsoft SMB Signing Information Disclosure Vulnerability

result.description:
Overview: This host is disabled SMB signing and is prone to information disclosure vulnerability.
Vulnerability Insight: The flaw is caused due to disabling SMB signing. Malicious users could sniff network traffic, capture, and reply to SMB transactions that are not signed by performing a man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack to obtain sensitive information.
Impact: Successful exploitation could allow remote attackers to gain sensitive information.
Impact Level: System
Affected Software/OS: Microsoft Windows NT Server 4.0 and prior. Microsoft Windows 2K Service Pack 4 and prior Microsoft Windows XP Service Pack 3 and prior Microsoft Windows 2003 Service Pack 2 and prior
Fix: Run Windows Update and update the listed hotfixes or download and update mentioned hotfixes in the advisory from the below link, http://support.microsoft.com/kb/916846
References: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/887429 http://support.microsoft.com/kb/916846 http://xforce.iss.net/xforce/xfdb/31965
Open UDP ports: [None found]
Open UDP ports: [None found]
The tool "smbclient" is not available for openvasd. Therefore none of the tests using smbclient are executed.

Synopsis :
The remote service implements TCP timestamps.
Description :
The remote host implements TCP timestamps, as defined by RFC1323. A side effect of this feature is that the uptime of the remote host can sometimes be computed.
See also :
http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1323.txt
